chunks.miniTeach: A comparator like (i, j) -> (i < j) ? -1 : (i == j ? 0 : 1) fails for Integer inputs. i < j auto-unboxes and compares values, but i == j compares object identity for boxed Integers. Two distinct Integer(42) objects are not == even though their values are equal. Use equals() or unbox first and compare primitives.
chunks.question: Explain why a comparator using (i == j) fails for Integer values and how to fix it.
expectedPoints: == on Integer compares object identity, not value
Two different Integer(42) are not identical objects
Fix by equals() or unbox to int before comparing

chunks.question: Define osmosis and direction of water flow.
expectedPoints: From low solute (high water) to high solute

chunks.miniTeach: Big-O notation characterizes an algorithm’s growth rate: O(1) constant, O(log n) logarithmic, O(n) linear, O(n log n) near-linear, O(n^2) quadratic. It abstracts constant factors to compare scalability.
chunks.question: Contrast O(n) vs O(n log n) with typical examples.
expectedPoints: O(n log n): efficient sorts (merge/quick sort average)
As n grows, n log n outpaces n by a log factor

chunks.miniTeach: A comparator like (i, j) -> (i < j) ? -1 : (i == j ? 0 : 1) fails for Integer inputs. i < j auto-unboxes and compares values, but i == j compares object identity for boxed Integers. Two distinct Integer(42) objects are not == even though their values are equal. Use equals() or unbox first and compare primitives.
chunks.question: Explain why a comparator using (i == j) fails for Integer values and how to fix it.
expectedPoints: == on Integer compares object identity, not value
Two different Integer(42) are not identical objects
Fix by equals() or unbox to int before comparing

chunks.miniTeach: Recursion solves a problem by solving smaller instances. Requires a base case and a step reducing the problem size. Beware of stack overflows and ensure progress toward the base case.
chunks.question: What two parts must every recursive function have?
expectedPoints: A base case that stops recursion
A recursive step that reduces the problem
Progress toward the base case to terminate

expectedPoints: Identify prior P(A), likelihood P(B|A), evidence P(B)

chunks.miniTeach: Java has primitive types (int, long, double, boolean) and their boxed counterparts (Integer, Long, Double, Boolean). Primitives hold raw values and are faster; boxed types are objects with identity and can be null. Beware: == compares identity for objects, not value; auto-unboxing can throw NullPointerException when a null is unboxed; repeated boxing/unboxing harms performance.
chunks.question: List three practical dangers of using boxed primitives where primitives would suffice in Java.
expectedPoints: == compares identity on boxed values (not numeric equality)
Performance overhead due to boxing/unboxing and allocations

chunks.miniTeach: A comparator like (i, j) -> (i < j) ? -1 : (i == j ? 0 : 1) fails for Integer inputs. i < j auto-unboxes and compares values, but i == j compares object identity for boxed Integers. Two distinct Integer(42) objects are not == even though their values are equal. Use equals() or unbox first and compare primitives.
chunks.question: Explain why a comparator using (i == j) fails for Integer values and how to fix it.
expectedPoints: == on Integer compares object identity, not value
Two different Integer(42) are not identical objects
Fix by equals() or unbox to int before comparing

chunks.miniTeach: Java has primitive types (int, long, double, boolean) and their boxed counterparts (Integer, Long, Double, Boolean). Primitives hold raw values and are faster; boxed types are objects with identity and can be null. Beware: == compares identity for objects, not value; auto-unboxing can throw NullPointerException when a null is unboxed; repeated boxing/unboxing harms performance.

expectedPoints: == compares identity on boxed values (not numeric equality)
Performance overhead due to boxing/unboxing and allocations

chunks.miniTeach: Java has primitive types (int, long, double, boolean) and their boxed counterparts (Integer, Long, Double, Boolean). Primitives hold raw values and are faster; boxed types are objects with identity and can be null. expectedPoints: == compares identity on boxed values (not numeric equality)
Performance overhead due to boxing/unboxing and allocations

chunks.question: Contrast O(n) vs O(n log n) with typical examples.
expectedPoints: O(n log n): efficient sorts (merge/quick sort average)

chunks.miniTeach: Java has primitive types (int, long, double, boolean) and their boxed counterparts (Integer, Long, Double, Boolean). chunks.question: List three practical dangers of using boxed primitives where primitives would suffice in Java.
expectedPoints: == compares identity on boxed values (not numeric equality)
Performance overhead due to boxing/unboxing and allocations

Beware: == compares identity for objects, not value; auto-unboxing can throw NullPointerException when a null is unboxed; repeated boxing/unboxing harms performance.
chunks.question: List three practical dangers of using boxed primitives where primitives would suffice in Java.
expectedPoints: == compares identity on boxed values (not numeric equality)
Performance overhead due to boxing/unboxing and allocations

chunks.miniTeach: Cellular respiration extracts energy from glucose via glycolysis, the citric acid (Krebs) cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation. Electrons from NADH/FADH2 drive the electron transport chain to power ATP synthesis by ATP synthase.
chunks.question: Name the three main stages of cellular respiration and the ATP-yielding step.
expectedPoints: ATP primarily generated in oxidative phosphorylation
ETC creates proton gradient used by ATP synthase

chunks.miniTeach: A comparator like (i, j) -> (i < j) ? -1 : (i == j ? 0 : 1) fails for Integer inputs. i < j auto-unboxes and compares values, but i == j compares object identity for boxed Integers. Two distinct Integer(42) objects are not == even though their values are equal. Use equals() or unbox first and compare primitives.
chunks.question: Explain why a comparator using (i == j) fails for Integer values and how to fix it.
expectedPoints: == on Integer compares object identity, not value
Two different Integer(42) are not identical objects
Fix by equals() or unbox to int before comparing

expectedPoints: Isolated system entropy does not decrease

expectedPoints: Identify prior P(A), likelihood P(B|A), evidence P(B)

expectedPoints: == compares identity on boxed values (not numeric equality)

chunks.miniTeach: A comparator like (i, j) -> (i < j) ? -1 : (i == j ? 0 : 1) fails for Integer inputs. i < j auto-unboxes and compares values, but i == j compares object identity for boxed Integers. Two distinct Integer(42) objects are not == even though their values are equal. Use equals() or unbox first and compare primitives.
chunks.question: Explain why a comparator using (i == j) fails for Integer values and how to fix it.
expectedPoints: == on Integer compares object identity, not value
Two different Integer(42) are not identical objects
Fix by equals() or unbox to int before comparing

chunks.question: State the two stages of photosynthesis and their roles.
expectedPoints: Light-dependent reactions generate ATP and NADPH
Calvin cycle fixes CO2 into sugars

chunks.miniTeach: Java has primitive types (int, long, double, boolean) and their boxed counterparts (Integer, Long, Double, Boolean). Primitives hold raw values and are faster; boxed types are objects with identity and can be null. Beware: == compares identity for objects, not value; auto-unboxing can throw NullPointerException when a null is unboxed; repeated boxing/unboxing harms performance.
chunks.question: List three practical dangers of using boxed primitives where primitives would suffice in Java.
expectedPoints: == compares identity on boxed values (not numeric equality)
Performance overhead due to boxing/unboxing and allocations

chunks.miniTeach: Java has primitive types (int, long, double, boolean) and their boxed counterparts (Integer, Long, Double, Boolean). Primitives hold raw values and are faster; boxed types are objects with identity and can be null. Beware: == compares identity for objects, not value; auto-unboxing can throw NullPointerException when a null is unboxed; repeated boxing/unboxing harms performance.
chunks.question: List three practical dangers of using boxed primitives where primitives would suffice in Java.
expectedPoints: == compares identity on boxed values (not numeric equality)
Performance overhead due to boxing/unboxing and allocations

chunks.miniTeach: A comparator like (i, j) -> (i < j) ? -1 : (i == j ? 0 : 1) fails for Integer inputs. i < j auto-unboxes and compares values, but i == j compares object identity for boxed Integers. Two distinct Integer(42) objects are not == even though their values are equal. Use equals() or unbox first and compare primitives.
chunks.question: Explain why a comparator using (i == j) fails for Integer values and how to fix it.
expectedPoints: == on Integer compares object identity, not value

Fix by equals() or unbox to int before comparing

chunks.question: Explain why a comparator using (i == j) fails for Integer values and how to fix it.
expectedPoints: == on Integer compares object identity, not value
Two different Integer(42) are not identical objects
Fix by equals() or unbox to int before comparing

chunks.question: What happens when price is above equilibrium?

chunks.miniTeach: Java has primitive types (int, long, double, boolean) and their boxed counterparts (Integer, Long, Double, Boolean). Primitives hold raw values and are faster; boxed types are objects with identity and can be null. Beware: == compares identity for objects, not value; auto-unboxing can throw NullPointerException when a null is unboxed; repeated boxing/unboxing harms performance.
chunks.question: List three practical dangers of using boxed primitives where primitives would suffice in Java.
expectedPoints: == compares identity on boxed values (not numeric equality)
Performance overhead due to boxing/unboxing and allocations

chunks.miniTeach: Big-O notation characterizes an algorithm’s growth rate: O(1) constant, O(log n) logarithmic, O(n) linear, O(n log n) near-linear, O(n^2) quadratic. It abstracts constant factors to compare scalability.
chunks.question: Contrast O(n) vs O(n log n) with typical examples.
expectedPoints: O(n log n): efficient sorts (merge/quick sort average)
As n grows, n log n outpaces n by a log factor

expectedPoints: Light-dependent reactions generate ATP and NADPH

Beware: == compares identity for objects, not value; auto-unboxing can throw NullPointerException when a null is unboxed; repeated boxing/unboxing harms performance.
chunks.question: List three practical dangers of using boxed primitives where primitives would suffice in Java.
expectedPoints: == compares identity on boxed values (not numeric equality)
Performance overhead due to boxing/unboxing and allocations

chunks.miniTeach: A comparator like (i, j) -> (i < j) ? -1 : (i == j ? 0 : 1) fails for Integer inputs. i < j auto-unboxes and compares values, but i == j compares object identity for boxed Integers. Two distinct Integer(42) objects are not == even though their values are equal. Use equals() or unbox first and compare primitives.
chunks.question: Explain why a comparator using (i == j) fails for Integer values and how to fix it.
expectedPoints: == on Integer compares object identity, not value
Two different Integer(42) are not identical objects
Fix by equals() or unbox to int before comparing

chunks.question: Explain why a comparator using (i == j) fails for Integer values and how to fix it.
expectedPoints: == on Integer compares object identity, not value
Two different Integer(42) are not identical objects
Fix by equals() or unbox to int before comparing

expectedPoints: ATP primarily generated in oxidative phosphorylation
ETC creates proton gradient used by ATP synthase

chunks.miniTeach: Java has primitive types (int, long, double, boolean) and their boxed counterparts (Integer, Long, Double, Boolean). Primitives hold raw values and are faster; boxed types are objects with identity and can be null. Beware: == compares identity for objects, not value; auto-unboxing can throw NullPointerException when a null is unboxed; repeated boxing/unboxing harms performance.
chunks.question: List three practical dangers of using boxed primitives where primitives would suffice in Java.
expectedPoints: == compares identity on boxed values (not numeric equality)
Performance overhead due to boxing/unboxing and allocations

Photosynthesis has light-dependent reactions (ATP, NADPH) and the Calvin cycle (fixes CO2 to sugar). Occurs in chloroplasts: thylakoids and stroma. Big-O compares growth rates: O(1), O(log n), O(n), O(n log n), O(n^2). Abstracts constants to reason about scalability. Bayes: P(A|B) = P(B|A)P(A)/P(B). Posterior equals likelihood times prior over evidence. Glycolysis, Krebs cycle, oxidative phosphorylation. ETC builds proton gradient, ATP synthase generates ATP.

expectedPoints: == does identity comparison for boxed types
